queue.fact_text: In 1972, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman returned to a newborn Bangladesh after more than nine months in a Pakistani prison, stepping off the plane to cheering crowds. Often called the "Father of the Nation," his return symbolized the survival and self-determination of a country just emerging from a brutal war of independence.

queue.fact_text: On January 10, 1981, the Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front (FMLN) launched its first major offensive in the Salvadoran Civil War, seizing large areas in Morazán and Chalatenango. The coordinated attacks signaled that a guerrilla coalition could challenge a heavily armed government for years to come.

episode.title: Morning Drops #25 - A Trip-Hop Journey

queue.fact_text: In 1990, Time Inc. and Warner Communications merged to form Time Warner, creating one of the world’s largest media conglomerates. The deal bundled magazines, movies, music labels, and television into a single corporate web, foreshadowing the media mega-mergers of the digital age.

episode.title: Morning Drops #13 - Demystifying Reggaeton

queue.fact_text: On January 10, 2003, North Korea announced it was withdrawing from the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, the first country ever to do so. The move jolted global diplomacy, raising urgent questions about how to prevent the spread of nuclear technology without cooperative rules.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

queue.fact_text: In 2007, a massive general strike erupted in Guinea, uniting trade unions and civil society in an effort to force President Lansana Conté to resign. The country ground to a halt as protesters challenged decades of authoritarian rule and economic hardship.

queue.fact_text: On January 10, 2015, a collision between an oil tanker and a passenger coach near Karachi, Pakistan turned the highway into an inferno, killing at least 62 people. The crash highlighted how fuel, infrastructure, and safety standards can turn routine travel into sudden catastrophe.

queue.fact_text: In 2019, 13-year-old Jayme Closs escaped from a remote house in Wisconsin after being held captive for 88 days by the man who had murdered her parents. Her survival and self-rescue stunned investigators and turned her into a symbol of endurance in the face of unimaginable trauma.

queue.fact_text: On January 10, 1901, while oil was gushing in Texas, another kind of power was quietly being tested in laboratories: radio waves were becoming tools to map the invisible. The same electromagnetic spectrum that carries music to your headphones is used to probe storms, image galaxies, and bounce signals off planetary surfaces.

episode.title: Morning Drops #26 - Canserbero
episode.description: Yasmin guides us through the story of Canserbero, the Venezuelan rapper who reshaped Latin American hip hop with his raw voice and deeply reflective lyrics. queue.fact_text: In AD 69, amid a chaotic "Year of the Four Emperors," Lucius Calpurnius Piso Licinianus was appointed heir by Emperor Galba—only to be murdered alongside him a few days later in a coup. His brief elevation and sudden fall show how volatile imperial succession could be when armies and elites were restless.

episode.title: Morning Drops #10 - The One With Many Names
episode.description: Yasmin guides us through the glamorous world of Ghost, the Swedish band that turned rock into ritual. From masked clergy to shifting identities, diving into the music and myth of one of the most theatrical acts of our time.

queue.fact_text: In 2015, the tanker–coach collision near Karachi was also a stark reminder of how heavily modern life relies on fossil fuels—especially in fast-growing cities. queue.fact_text: On this day in 1984, as Washington and the Vatican exchanged ambassadors again, another, quieter shift was underway: global pop culture was increasingly blending sacred symbols with secular sounds. From cathedrals in film to spiritual samples in electronic music, the boundary between ritual and entertainment was blurring.

published.fact_text: In 1946, U.S. Army engineers beamed powerful radar pulses at the Moon in an experiment called Project Diana and, for the first time, heard their own radio signal echo back from another celestial body. It proved that Earth could use radio waves to communicate beyond its atmosphere, laying groundwork for deep-space tracking and interplanetary communication.

published.fact_text: On the same day in 1946, delegates from 51 nations gathered in London for the very first session of the United Nations General Assembly. In a building normally used for church services, they laid the foundations for a new experiment in global cooperation after the devastation of World War II.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb

published.fact_text: In 1917, after being stranded for months on the frozen edge of Antarctica, seven members of Shackleton’s Ross Sea party were finally rescued. They had endured scurvy, extreme cold, and the deaths of companions while continuing their mission to lay vital supply depots for explorers who never came.

episode.title: Morning Drops #36 - Diving With Orcas

published.match_reason: Both stories unfold in icy waters near the poles, blending human endurance with the haunting, cinematic mood of high-latitude seas.

published.fact_text: On January 10, 1927, Fritz Lang’s Metropolis premiered in Germany, introducing one of cinema’s first sprawling futuristic cities and an iconic robot double. The film’s towering machines, class struggle, and expressionist visuals helped define the look and politics of science fiction for almost a century.

published.fact_text: In 49 BC, Julius Caesar led a single legion across the small Italian river Rubicon, an apparently simple march that amounted to a declaration of war on the Roman Senate. The act was so decisive that “crossing the Rubicon” still means taking an irreversible step with enormous consequences.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1901, a drilling crew near Beaumont, Texas hit the Spindletop oil reservoir, and crude oil erupted more than 45 meters into the air for nine days. The gusher kicked off the Texas Oil Boom, flooding the world with cheap petroleum and reshaping industry, transport, and geopolitics.

published.fact_text: In 1812, the steamboat New Orleans completed the first steam-powered journey down the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers, arriving in New Orleans 82 days after leaving Pittsburgh. Its voyage proved that bulky river transport could be driven by engines rather than sails or muscle, altering trade and travel across the American interior.

published.fact_text: In 1861, Florida became the third U.S. state to secede from the Union, joining a chain reaction that would ignite the American Civil War. Leaders saw the decision as a defense of states’ rights and slavery, but it plunged the region into one of the bloodiest conflicts in U.S. history.

published.fact_text: On January 10, 1941, in the midst of World War II’s Balkan campaign, Greek forces captured the Kleisoura Pass (Klisura) from Italian troops. This mountain pass became a symbol of a smaller nation’s unexpected resistance in difficult terrain against a supposedly superior army.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1954, BOAC Flight 781, a pioneering de Havilland Comet jet airliner, broke apart mid-flight over the Tyrrhenian Sea, killing all 35 on board. The tragedy led to one of the earliest deep forensic investigations in aviation, revealing metal fatigue and fundamentally changing how aircraft are designed and tested.

episode.title: Morning Drops #43 - Looking Back
episode.description:
In this first Morning Drop of 2026, Yasmin opens a space for quiet reflection on the nature of transitions. The episode traces a personal journey that began three years ago, when a sudden injury on New Year’s Day turned a desire for movement into a mandatory season of stillness.

Through the story of a broken knee and the slow process of relearning to walk, the narrative explores the difference between being strong and being aware. It touches on the vulnerability of the body, the unexpected joy found in daily progress, and the warmth that comes from finally allowing oneself to accept help. The musical selection mirrors this path of recovery, moving from the uncertainty of change to the steady rhythm of healing.

Mood: Reflective, Resilient, Grounded
Music genre: Indie Pop, Cinematic, World, Soul

We invite you to listen deeply and find comfort in your own pace.
songs: Kelly Finnigan - I Don't Wanna Wait
Goran Bregović & Iggy Pop - This Is a Film

published.match_reason: A catastrophic early jet crash that reshaped safety meets a reflective episode about confronting vulnerability, learning from trauma, and carefully rebuilding.

published.fact_text: In 1980, The New England Journal of Medicine published a brief letter titled "Addiction Rare in Patients Treated with Narcotics"—just five sentences long. Decades later, this tiny, non-rigorous note was repeatedly cited out of context to downplay opioid risks, helping fuel a massive addiction crisis.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.
